headline.main: 300 Million of Us, and Counting (5 Letters)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One hundred million people ago, when the population was 200 million, a commission proposed by President Nixon in 1969 (inspired by Daniel Patrick Moynihan) reached a very different assessment of our population numbers than the unalloyed enthusiasm of your Oct. 11 editorial ''300 Million.''
docs.abstract: Five letters comment on Oct 11 editorial on projected arrival of 300 millionth American; Charles F Westoff says that when population was 200 million, commission proposed by Pres Nixon in 1969 reached very different assessment of our population numbers than unalloyed enthusiasm of Oct 11 editorial; Westoff notes that he was executive director of commission; Christopher S Edwards says dismissing current concerns about America's rapid population growth chiefly as fears of right-wing xenophobes ignores polling data indicating that majority of Americans do not want further population growth; Larry Geni says editorial's contention that population issues have mysterious ways of working themselves out is dangerous oversimplification; Population Connection pres John Seager notes that 35 percent of US births are unplanned; drawing; Christopher Wood says editorial is shortsighted
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     One hundred million people ago, when the population was 200 million, a commission proposed by President Nixon in 1969 (inspired by Daniel Patrick Moynihan) reached a very different assessment of our population numbers than the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Véronique Courjault, a Frenchwoman wanted in South Korea on possible infanticide charges after twin baby boys were found in a freezer in her home in Seoul in July, has admitted to killing the children, her lawyer said. After a French DNA test confirmed that she was the mother, Ms. Courjault, 38, reversed almost three months of denials and confessed to the French police that she killed them just after their birth in 2003. She said she had hid the pregnancy from her husband, an auto industry employee based in South Korea. The couple had denied the children were theirs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Véronique Courjault, a Frenchwoman wanted in South Korea on possible infanticide charges after twin baby boys were found in a freezer in her home in Seoul in July, has admitted to killing the children, her lawyer said. After a French DNA test confirmed that she was the mother, Ms. Courjault, 38, reversed almost three months of denials and confessed to the French police that she killed them just after their birth in 2003. She said she had hid the pregnancy from her husband, an auto industry employee based in South Korea. The couple had denied the children were theirs. JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)
